full_conversation: Therapist: Welcome, Sarah. How are you feeling today?
Client: Hi, Dr. Thompson. I'm... I'm okay, I guess. A bit nervous about today's session.
Therapist: That's understandable. Remember, you're safe here.
Client: Thank you. I've been thinking a lot about what we discussed last time, about the cyberbullying incident. It's been hard to shake off those memories.
Therapist: You're very brave for confronting this. Shall we begin the exposure exercise?
Client: Yes, I think I'm ready. Though I'm feeling a bit anxious already.
Therapist: That's normal. Take a deep breath. When you're ready, describe the incident.
Client: Okay... It was about three months ago. I had posted a photo of myself on social media, just a casual selfie. At first, everything seemed fine, but then...
Therapist: You're doing well. Continue.

Client: The comments started coming in. At first, they were just a few negative ones, but then it snowballed. People I didn't even know were calling me ugly, fat, worthless. Someone even photoshopped my picture to make me look... grotesque.
Therapist: Stay with that feeling. You're safe here.
Client: It's hard... I remember feeling my heart racing, my hands shaking as I scrolled through the comments. I couldn't believe how cruel people could be. I felt so exposed, so vulnerable.
Therapist: You're handling this well. Keep going.

Client: I tried to delete the post, but screenshots were already circulating. It felt like I couldn't escape it. My phone kept buzzing with notifications, each one a new insult or threat. I remember curling up on my bed, just sobbing uncontrollably.
Therapist: It's okay to feel those emotions. You're doing great.

Client: I felt so alone, so humiliated. I couldn't bring myself to tell anyone what was happening. I was afraid they'd judge me or tell me I was overreacting. The worst part was, some of the comments were from people I thought were my friends.
Therapist: That must have been incredibly painful. You're very brave for sharing this.

Client: It was. I... I started having panic attacks. I couldn't sleep, couldn't eat. Every time my phone buzzed, I'd feel this wave of dread wash over me. I became paranoid, thinking everyone was laughing at me behind my back.
Therapist: You're doing an excellent job describing your experience. How are you feeling right now?
Client: I'm... I'm shaking a little. My heart's beating fast. But I think I can continue.
Therapist: Take a moment if you need to. You're in control here.

Client: Thank you. It's just... reliving it brings back all those feelings of shame and helplessness. I ended up deactivating all my social media accounts, but the damage was already done. I felt like I couldn't trust anyone anymore.
Therapist: It's understandable to feel that way. You're showing incredible strength.

Client: The worst part was how it affected my daily life. I became afraid to leave my house, worried that people would recognize me from the photos. I lost my job because I couldn't bring myself to go to work. It felt like my whole life had been destroyed by one innocent photo.
Therapist: You're navigating through this memory impressively. How are you feeling now?
Client: It's... it's intense. I can feel my chest tightening, but I'm trying to breathe through it. It's hard not to get caught up in those feelings of despair again.
Therapist: You're doing an amazing job. Remember, you're here now, you're safe.

Client: Thank you. It helps to hear that. I think... I think what hurt the most was feeling like I had no control over the situation. Once those comments and altered photos were out there, I couldn't take them back. I felt so powerless.
Therapist: That's a common feeling in these situations. You're handling it well.

Client: I started having nightmares about it. In my dreams, I'd be standing in a crowded room, and everyone would be pointing and laughing at me. I'd try to run, but I couldn't move. I'd wake up in a cold sweat, feeling just as trapped as I did in the dream.
Therapist: You're very brave for confronting these memories. How are you feeling right now?
Client: I'm... I'm okay. It's hard, but I think talking about it is helping. It doesn't feel quite as overwhelming as it did before.
Therapist: That's excellent progress. You should be proud of yourself.
Client: Thank you. I think... I think I'm starting to realize that those people who said those horrible things, they don't define me. Their words were cruel, but they don't determine my worth.
Therapist: That's a powerful realization. You're showing great insight.

Client: It's still hard, though. Sometimes I catch myself hesitating before I post anything online, or second-guessing my appearance. But I'm trying to remind myself that I'm more than what others think of me.
Therapist: That's an important step. You're doing really well.
Client: I think... I think I'm ready to stop for now. This has been intense, but I feel like I've made some progress.
Therapist: You've done an incredible job today, Sarah. How are you feeling as we wrap up?
Client: I feel... drained, but also a bit lighter. Like I've let go of some of the weight I've been carrying. Thank you for guiding me through this.
Therapist: You're very welcome. You've shown remarkable courage today.
